historySnippet.reasoning: Agency is already above the 0.75 threshold and still rising (dA/dt>0) while complexity is slightly decaying, so I’ll keep U at the best-record level and reduce k_A_decay (which historically produced the biggest A gains) plus slightly reduce k_C_decay to stabilize C and sustain A’s upward trajectory.

Agency is already above the 0.75 threshold and still rising (dA/dt=0.0030), so to preserve the winning configuration near the best-record U=0.10 while accelerating A further, I’ll keep U steady and reduce the unusually high k_A_decay (currently 0.100 vs best-record 0.005) to prevent unnecessary agency loss (noting past k_A_decay tweaks were high-impact, including the big drop at Gen 744.7).

A is already well above 0.75 but is fading mainly because k_A_decay is currently much higher than the best-record setting (0.02 vs 0.005) and D is starting to collapse, so I’ll revert decay toward the best while keeping U at the proven 0.10 to stabilize A without increasing selection pressure (history shows large A drops when decay tweaks overshoot, e.g., Gen 744.7).

Agency is already well above the 0.75 objective and still rising, and since the best record occurred at U=0.10 with essentially the same parameter regime (while past aggressive k_A_decay/k_D_decay tweaks caused large drops, e.g., Gen 744.7), I’ll keep U steady and make only a tiny decay reduction to sustain A without destabilizing C/D.

A is already well above 0.75 and still rising, but D is collapsing (dD/dt=-0.007) so I’ll keep U at the proven-best 0.10 while reducing diversity loss via a small k_D_decay decrease (historically k_D_decay tweaks have improved A, e.g., Gen 687.1 and 906.0) to preserve long-run open-endedness without risking an A crash like the large drop at Gen 744.7.

A is already safely >0.75 but all derivatives are negative (C, D, A fading), so I’ll keep U at the proven-best 0.10 while stabilizing the slide by slightly reducing decay terms (avoiding big shifts given past large A drops when k_A_decay was perturbed too aggressively).

A is already above target but slightly fading while D is barely declining, so I’ll keep U at the proven best (0.10) and make a minimal stabilizing tweak by lowering k_A_decay a bit (history shows reducing k_A_decay strongly improved A at Gen 860.3) while easing diversity loss via a small k_D_decay reduction.

Agency is already safely above 0.75 but is slightly fading (dA/dt < 0); since past gains came from lowering k_A_decay (e.g., Gen 860.3) and current settings are close to the best record, make a small stabilizing tweak to k_A_decay while keeping U at the best-performing 0.10 to avoid destabilizing C/D.

Agency is already safely above 0.75 and still rising while Complexity is slightly decaying, so I’ll keep U at the best-record value (0.10) and slightly reduce k_C_decay to stabilize C without perturbing the proven A dynamics (history shows k_A_decay/k_D_decay tweaks can cause volatility).

A is already فوق 0.75 but is slightly fading while D is collapsing, so I’ll keep U near the best-record 0.10 and reduce diversity loss (k_D_decay) plus slightly boost diversity->complexity coupling (k_CD) to stabilize D without adding selection pressure; this is safer than a phase-shift given we’re near peak A and past small k_A_decay tweaks have been mixed.

name: Slow-Decay Agency Weaver
description: This agent crossed the threshold by progressively suppressing internal losses—especially Agency decay (k_A_decay=0.0015) and Complexity decay (k_C_decay=0.09)—after an early over-adjustment caused a dip around Gen 804. Its emergence looks like a long, incremental climb driven by repeated fine-tuning of decay terms (multiple rises after k_A_decay and k_D_decay updates), maintaining high Complexity/Diversity (C≈0.828, D≈0.832) under low external difficulty (U=0.10) rather than surviving a harsh spike. The near-max coupling from difficulty into agency response (k_AU=0.99) suggests it is highly sensitive to environmental pressure, but it “wins” here by conserving gains and letting diversity grow without violating bounds.
